provenance.note: Perhaps acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; perhaps acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Joseph Hogarth, sold Southgate and Barrett's auction, 15 June 1854, lot 2784 (£1 to Olwen, possibly the code name for a dealer); the dealer Francis Harvey, offered Foster and Son auction, 21 May 1862, lot 11 (bought-in at £3.5s.); George A. Smith, sold Christie's, 16 July 1880, lot 90 (£4.4s. to the dealer Francis Harvey); William Bell Scott, sold Sotheby's, 21 April 1885, lot 173 (£12.15s. to Thibaudeau acting for the British Museum).

objnote.p: "The House of Death" is based on Adam's vision of "a Lazar-house" in John Milton's *Paradise Lost*, Book 11, lines 477-93. "Triumphant Death" hovers above the stricken, his "Dart[s]" descending below each hand. The curved form extending between his hands seems poised ambiguously between a bow and a scroll. The figure far right, with a dagger in his left hand, may be a personification of Milton's "despair" who "tended the sick."

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper center of the design hovers a god-like figure, probably personified Death, in accord with the passage illustrated from Milton's Paradise Lost. His eyes are closed and he has an unusually long, flowing beard. He hovers above or within a cloud. Beneath his raised arms and hands appears a bow-shaped scroll with coiled ends. Arrow-like darts descend from either the figure or the scroll, two on each side of his beard. Three figures lie in pain on a heavy woven mat below Death. We see the head and upper body of a fourth figure proped up behind those lying on the mat. All four are probably dying. A figure along the right margin of the design stands, or walks towards the left, with his head hanging low, while holding a dagger in his left hand. He may be a personification of "despair" in Milton's text. In the middle distance, right side of the cloud, is a hunched-over figure whose hands clasp either side of his head.

component.illusobjdesc: An old man with long, spiky hair and an unusually long, flowing beard hovers in the upper center of, or is hovering just above, a cloud. We see only his arms, hands, head, enormous beard, and possibly something of his gown or long shirt between the lower locks of his beard. This shirt or gown clearly covers his arms. His eyes are closed, or possibly sealed to indicate blindness, and his arms are raised horizontally with his palms facing down. A bow-like scroll extends between his hands; he may be holding it. The fingers of both hands are carefully delineated. Four arrow-like darts descend diagonally from either the scroll or the figure, a pair on each side of his beard. This god-like figure is probably a personification of Death, in accord with the passage illustrated in Milton's Paradise Lost.
A cloud appears below the top center figure, possibly supporting him. It, or another cloud, appears on both sides of his head and extends to the margin of the design on the right.

A bow-like scroll with coiled ends extends between the hands of the top center figure. Arrow-like darts descend from the scroll, or possibly from the figure, two left of his beard and two right of his beard.

A nude, bald, and muscular male, just within the right margin of the design, stands (or walks towards the left) with his head bowed down. His left eye stares blankly downward. His skin is dark and slightly greenish. He holds a dagger in his left hand with his forefinger along the blade. His left arm is at his side. The figure’s left ear is prominent. He probably personifies "despair" in the passage illustrated in Milton's *Paradise Lost*.

The muscular male lying on the mat, closest to the viewer, is nude, with his genital area exposed but not delineated in detail. While his head and upper body are bent towards the mat, the bottom half of his body (hips and below) faces the viewer; this is particularly true of the right leg, which lies in front of the left leg, crossing the left leg at the ankle. The left arm is sharply bent upwards as his left hand grips his left shoulder. The right arm is most likely bent as well, suggested by the right forearm visible underneath his torso (although the rest of the arm is not pictured). His right fingers are nestled between his left bicep and his left forearm (all four fingers are discernible). Thus, his arms are wrapped around his upper body. His face, as well as his twisted posture, express despair and pain. He has short (?) curly hair. He is probably diseased and dying.

The second man from the front on the mat is nude and lies supine. His chest is arched upward. His tensed body, backward bent head, and slightly opened mouth suggest that he is in pain. His arms are not pictured. The back of his head with long hair lies on top of the mat. His face is facing to the left, although upside down. His right ear is clearly delineated. His eyes may be rolled back in his head, or perhaps raised, and he is probably diseased and dying.

Along with the two front-most figures, the third nude male from the viewer on the mat lies on his right side and faces the viewer. His eyes are turned upwards and his mouth is opened wide; he may be howling in pain. His facial expression suggests a mixture of despair and pain. His hair is between short and long; he may be bearded. His left knee is drawn up towards his chest; his left leg appears to be crossed over his right leg. Both feet, but particularly the left, are prominent. He is probably diseased and dying, like his companions on the mat.

Beneath the three men is a large braided or rope-like straw(?) mat or carpet that spans the entire bottom margin of the design. Perhaps we see a narrow strip of uncovered floor along the bottom margin of the design, possibly with a shadow on the right.
In the lower left corner, the third figure from the front appears to rest his head on or in front of a small mound or pillow of straw, not woven like the mat.

A bald male in the middle distance just inside the left margin (fourth figure from the front) is visible, nude, from the stomach up. He looks up in right profile towards Death with his mouth slightly open, as if in terror. His right ear is prominent. He is probably half-sitting, half-lying, with his upper body propped up on his arms. His right shoulder cradles his head, which is bent severely backwards. He is probably diseased and dying.

In the middle distance right of the cloud is a (male?) figure who faces the viewer and bows his head to the ground. We see only the top of his head, a little of his arms, his hands, and his (gowned?) back. Both of the figure's hands are raised, palms vertical, parallel to the sides of his head. His hair is between long and short; his posture suggests despair.
The background of the design (behind the figures on the left and right) is dark, suggesting an ominous atmosphere.
